chapter: Diseases in Neonates requiring Special Care

questions.question: A preterm neonate delivered one hour back in a PHC is rushed to the district hospital. There is an evisceration of bowel loops from a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Gastroschisis is a congenital defect in the abdominal wall, typically to the right of the umbilicus, that results in the evisceration of bowel loops.

questions.question: While performing the head-to-toe examination in a term 2.6kg neonate, a large, wide anterior fontanelle is noted. Which of the following congenital anomalies is least likely?
questions.explanation: In craniosynostosis, infants have small fontanelles. Craniosynostosis is the premature fusion of cranial sutures. An infant has two fontanelles at birth, the diamond-shaped anterior fontanelle and the triangular posterior fontanelle. Closure of the anterior fontanelle occurs at 18 months. Closure of the posterior fontanelle occurs by the 6th - 8th week after birth; its persistence suggests underlying hydrocephalus or congenital hypothyroidism. The presence of a third fontanelle may suggest trisomy 21 or prematurity. The persistence of excessively large anterior fontanelles and small fontanelles has been associated with several disorders: Large fontanelles - Achondroplasia, Cleidocranial dysostosis, Congenital rubella syndrome, Hydrocephaly. Small fontanelles - Microcephaly, Craniosynostosis, Congenital hyperthyroidism, Wormian bones, Osteogenesis imperfecta, Prematurity, Russell-Silver syndrome, Trisomies 13, 18, and 21, Vitamin D deficiency, rickets.

questions.question: An anxious new mother brings her 18-day-old baby to the casualty with complaints of poor feeding and yellowish discoloration of the skin. In the casualty, the baby had an episode of seizure. His total bilirubin is 32 mg/dl and he is diagnosed to have kernicterus. Which of the following will not be seen as a late feature of the disease?
questions.explanation: Hypotonia is seen in the early phase of kernicterus. Kernicterus or bilirubin encephalopathy is a neurological syndrome resulting from the deposition of unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin in the basal ganglia and brainstem nuclei. It can result in permanent brain damage. Early Phase (Acute) and Late Phase symptoms include: Poor suck, Stupor, Hypotonia, Seizures, Movement disorders - choreoathetosis, ballismus, tremor, Sensorineural hearing loss, and Defective upward gaze.

questions.question: What is the most common cause of seizures in a term neonate?
questions.explanation:
Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) is the most common cause of neonatal seizures in term babies. Seizures due to HIE typically appear within the first 12-24 hours of birth. Subtle seizures are the most common type of seizures in neonates with HIE. Neonatal seizures: 
   • Most common type - Subtle seizures
   • Least common type - Myoclonic seizures
   • Most common metabolic cause - Hypoglycemia
   • Investigation of choice for the diagnosis of seizures - Electroencephalogram (EEG)
   • Neuroimaging modality of choice for etiological evaluation - MRI
   • Drug of choice - Phenobarbitone

questions.question: A 2-day-old neonate was admitted to the NICU after he was observed to have movements as shown in the clip. His APGAR scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. His blood sugar was within the normal range in the first 24 hours. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The video clip of a 2-day-old neonate exhibiting repetitive, rhythmic movement in unilateral upper and lower limbs suggests a neonatal seizure of focal clonic type. A focal clonic seizure is characterized by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups of the limbs, face, or trunk, maybe unifocal or multifocal. It may occur synchronously or asynchronously in muscle groups on one side of the body. It may occur simultaneously but asynchronously on both sides. It cannot be suppressed by restraint. Other options: Option A: Focal tonic seizures are characterized by sustained posturing of a single limb, sustained asymmetrical posturing of the trunk, and sustained eye deviation. They cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint. Option C: Spasms are sudden generalized jerks lasting 1-2 seconds and are usually associated with a single, very brief, generalized discharge. They may be flexor, extensor, or mixed extensor/flexor and can occur in clusters. They too cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint. Option D: Subtle seizures include transient eye deviations, nystagmus, blinking, mouthing, abnormal extremity movements (rowing, swimming, cycling, pedaling), fluctuations in heart rate, hypertension episodes, and apnea. They are more common in preterm than in term babies. Myoclonic seizures are random, single, rapid muscle contractions of the limbs, face, or trunk. They are not repetitive or may recur at a slow rate. They can be generalized, focal, or fragmentary. They can be provoked by stimulation. Clinically apparent seizures in a neonate should be treated if they last >3 minutes or are brief serial seizures. In all neonates with seizures, hypoglycemia, CNS infection, and hypocalcemia should be ruled out before starting anti-epileptic drug treatment. Causes of neonatal seizure according to the age of presentation: 1 to 4 days: Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy, maternal use of narcotics or barbiturates, drug toxicity: lidocaine, penicillin, intraventricular hemorrhage, hypocalcemia, sepsis, hypoglycemia, hypomagnesemia, hypo or hypernatremia, galactosemia, urea cycle disorders. 4 to 14 days: Meningitis (bacterial), encephalitis (enteroviral, herpes simplex), hypocalcemia, hypoglycemia, galactosemia, fructosemia, hyperinsulinism, hyperammonemia syndrome. 2 to 8 weeks: Herpes simplex or enteroviral encephalitis, bacterial meningitis, subdural hematoma, child abuse, aminoaciduria, urea cycle defects, malformations of cortical development, tuberous sclerosis, Sturge-Weber syndrome.

questions.question: A term neonate born to a lady with chorioamnionitis is diagnosed with neonatal sepsis. Which of the following statements are false?
questions.explanation: Late-onset sepsis usually presents after 72 hours of age (not 48 hours). Neutropenia appears to be a better predictor of neonatal sepsis (not neutrophilia). Neonatal sepsis is a clinical syndrome characterized by signs and symptoms of infection, with or without accompanying bacteremia in the first month of life. Escherichia coli, Staphylococcus aureus, and Klebsiella spp. are the predominant organisms involved. Organisms such as Acinetobacter, Pseudomonas, and coagulase-negative staphylococci are also important pathogens in hospital-acquired infections. Early-onset sepsis and late-onset sepsis: Presentation, Source of infection, and Manifestation. Within the first 72 hours of life, after 72 hours of life, maternal genital tract, nosocomial or community-acquired, respiratory distress and pneumonia, septicemia, pneumonia, or meningitis.

questions.question: Blood cultures drawn from a late preterm baby on day 8 of life show the growth of Streptococcus species within 18 hours. An umbilical line tip culture also shows the same bacteria. Which among the following is the most common manifestation of the described type of neonatal sepsis?
questions.explanation: Bacterial growth in the umbilical tip and blood cultures on day 8 suggests a hospital-acquired infection after 72 hours. This is late-onset neonatal sepsis. The most common manifestation of late-onset neonatal sepsis is meningitis. Early-onset sepsis, Late-onset sepsis: Presentation, Source of infection, Presents within first 72 hours of life, Maternal genital tract, Presents after 72 hours of life, Nosocomial or community-acquired. NOTE: Early-onset sepsis, Late-onset sepsis: Manifestation, Respiratory distress and pneumonia, Septicemia, pneumonia, or meningitis. Traditionally, neonatal sepsis had been classified as EOS (<7 days) and LOS (>7 days), but recently, experts have come to believe that Early-onset neonatal sepsis manifests within the first 72 hours of life and Late-onset neonatal sepsis after 72 hours of life.

questions.question: A focus of Klebsiella is detected in one of the ventilators during a routine quality and maintenance check in the NICU. Sepsis protocol is enacted and a sepsis screen is ordered for all the neonates at risk. Which of the following investigations is not sent as part of a neonatal sepsis screen?
questions.explanation: Absolute eosinophil count is not a component of neonatal sepsis screen. The various components of the septic screen include: Total leukocyte count (TLC), Absolute neutrophil count (ANC), Immature: Total neutrophil ratio (IT), Micro-erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein. Blood culture: Gold standard for diagnosis. All neonates suspected to have sepsis should have a septic screen to corroborate the diagnosis. Note: Most common fungus causing neonatal sepsis: Candida species.

questions.question: Which of the following findings in a healthy term child would warrant further evaluation?
questions.explanation: Buphthalmos is not a normal finding in a newborn; it is suggestive of congenital glaucoma and should, therefore, be investigated. The sclera and cornea are more elastic in early childhood, and an increase in intraocular pressure (IOP), therefore, leads to an expansion of the globe and the development of buphthalmos ("ox eye"). Recommended screening for eye diseases at birth: • Buphthalmos • Cataract • Ophthalmia Neonatorum • Developmental anomalies - Microphthalmos, Anophthalmos • Nystagmus • Squint • Retinopathy of prematurity

questions.question: A neonate undergoing routine ophthalmological examination was found to have the findings shown below. Which among the following can be ruled out as the cause of this finding?
questions.explanation: The image shows leukokoria or white pupillary reflex. It is not seen in congenital glaucoma. Leukokoria is seen in: • Congenital cataract • Chorioretinitis • Retinoblastoma • Retinopathy of prematurity • Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous.

questions.question: A 26-year-old primigravida delivers a 1.5 kg baby girl at 27 weeks of gestation. When is an ophthalmological examination recommended for the initial screening of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) in this baby?

options.B: At age equivalent to 32 weeks of gestation

questions.explanation:
The first Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP) screening in this baby should be conducted at age equivalent to 32 weeks of gestation. Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP) is a vaso-proliferative disorder of the developing retinal blood vessels of the preterm infant, which may lead to poor visual acuity or blindness. Criteria for screening: 
      • Birth weight <2000g OR 
      • Gestational age <34 weeks OR 
      • Gestational age between 34-36 weeks with the following risk factors - prolonged oxygen therapy (respiratory distress syndrome, apnea, cardiorespiratory support), neonatal sepsis, blood/exchange transfusion. 
      According to IAP guidelines, ROP screening should be conducted according to the table given below: 
      Period of gestation (POG) / birth weight 
      <28 weeks OR <1200g: 2-3 weeks of postnatal age 
      >28 weeks OR >1200g: 4 weeks of postnatal age. 
      According to Nelson's 22nd edition, ROP screening should be conducted according to the table given below: 
      Screening 
      POG <28 weeks: 31 weeks of POG 
      28-32 weeks: 4 weeks of postnatal age. 
      Annual follow-up is carried out unless indicated otherwise in cases where cryotherapy/laser treatment or cycloplegic refraction has been done.

questions.question: An infant born 48 hours back by vaginal delivery with birth asphyxia develops seizures. What stage of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy is the child likely to be in?
questions.explanation: Seizures are common in stage 2 of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE). HIE is an important cause of permanent damage to CNS tissues, resulting in the following: Neonatal Death, Cerebral Palsy, Developmental Delay. Stage 1: Stupor, Stage 2: Seizures, Stage 3: Decerebration

questions.question: A 27-year-old primigravida delivers a 3kg term baby after a cesarean section done in view ofprolonged labor. The child cries 5 mins after birth and has a seizure 8 hours later. What is theimaging of choice for evaluation?
questions.explanation: The clinical vignette of prolonged labor, delayed cry after birth (birth asphyxia), and seizuresuggest hypoxic-ischemic injury. The preferred imaging modality in term neonates with HIE isdiffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). This is because of its increased sensitivityand specificity early in the process and its ability to outline the topography of the lesion.Computed Tomography (CT) is helpful in identifying focal hemorrhagic lesions, diffuse corticalinjury, and damage to the basal ganglia, but limited ability during the first few days of life.Ultrasonography (USG) - Neurosonogram is the initial preferred modality for preterm infants.Amplitude-integrated electroencephalography (aEEG) may help to determine which infants are atincreased risk for long-term brain injury.

questions.question: A 1.4 Kg neonate is born at 29 weeks of gestation. The sonologist performing aneurosonogram is most likely to find an intracranial hemorrhage in the:
questions.explanation: 53Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) in premature infants occurs in the gelatinous subependymalor germinal matrix.In preterm infants, the germinal matrix (situated ventrolateral to lateral ventricles) is extensiveand highly vascular which makes them prone to bleeding. Germinal matrix normally involutesduring the third trimester.Major neuropathologic lesions associated with very-low-birth-weight (VLBW) infants areintraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) and periventricular leukomalacia (PVL).Periventricular leukomalacia (PVL) is characterized by focal necrotic lesions in the periventricularwhite matter.

options.A: Proximal part of the ileum is involved most frequently
options.B: Pneumatosis intestinalis may be seenIt is associated with intestinal ischemiad) It is more common in preterm infantsQuestion 17:A 12-day old preterm neonate was diagnosed to have necrotizing enterocolitis. She had beenswitched over from breastmilk to formula feed 5 days after birth as the mother died ofCOVID-associated complications. Which of the following features will not be seen in thebaby?a) Vomitingb) Abdominal mass

questions.explanation: The distal ileum and the proximal colon are involved most frequently in necrotizing enterocolitis.Necrotizing enterocolitis is a multifactorial disease primarily associated with intestinal immaturitycharacterized by mucosal or transmural necrosis of the intestine. It is more common in preterminfants, and prematurity is the biggest risk factor.The triad of intestinal ischemia (injury), enteral nutrition (metabolic substrate), and bacterialtranslocation have classically been linked to necrotizing enterocolitis.Pathologic findings include necrotic segment(s) of intestine, gas accumulation in the submucosaof the bowel wall (pneumatosis intestinalis), and progression of the necrosis to perforation,peritonitis, sepsis, and death.Breast milk protects against necrotizing enterocolitis.
